questions.question: The tunica vaginalis is a part of:
questions.explanation: The tunica vaginalis is derived from the processus vaginalis, which is an outpouching of the peritoneum that descends into the scrotum with the testis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In incompletely descended testis, which of the following statements is false?
options: A testis absent from the scrotum after 3 months is unlikely to descend.
An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches.
Orchidopexy reduces the chances of developing a testicular tumour.
questions.explanation: Orchidopexy allows easier examination and early tumor detection but does not significantly lower malignancy risk, which remains higher than in the general population.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements are true about a hydrocele EXCEPT:
options: A hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis.
A congenital hydrocele causes an intermittent swelling.
An acute hydrocele in a young man may be a sinister finding.
Testicular pathology may cause a hydrocele.
questions.explanation: Simple aspiration/ drainage not effective as fluid always reaccumulates and there is a risk of introducing infection. Surgical treatment (excision or plication of the sac) is required.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Precocious puberty is a character of:
questions.explanation: Leydig cell tumors (interstitial cell tumors) secrete androgens (testosterone), which can cause isosexual precocious puberty in prepubertal boys.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The vaginal hydrocele is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Eversion and excision of the tunica is the main line of treatment.
The swelling is usually found above the neck of the scrotum.
May complicated by infection and pyocele
questions.explanation: Vaginal hydrocele surrounds the testis in scrotum.  not above the neck of the scrotum; swellings in that region are typically inguinal hernias or encysted hydroceles of the cord.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following are causes of unilateral testicular arrest EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Low maternal HCG is a hormonal factor that affects the body systemically, typically leading to bilateral undescended testes, not unilateral arrest.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard the embryology of testis all are correct EXCEPT:
options: Derives its blood supply directly from aorta.
Torsion only occurs on top of anomalous testis.
questions.explanation: The testis develops retroperitoneally (extraperitoneal) and descends behind the peritoneum. It is not an intraperitoneal structure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Best time for orchiopexy is:
questions.explanation: The optimal time for orchidopexy is between 6 and 12-18 months to prevent histological deterioration of the germ cells, which begins after the first year of life.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Best treatment for testicular torsion is:
options: Early operation to untwist the testis.
All of the above in sequence.
questions.explanation: Management includes resuscitation, urgent surgical detorsion, and orchidopexy of both the affected and contralateral testis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Best treatment of retractile testis is:
questions.explanation: Retractile testes are normal testes that retract due to a strong cremasteric reflex. They do not require surgery or hormonal therapy, only reassurance and follow-up.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Complications of varicocele include the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Varicocele can cause pain, testicular atrophy, and infertility, but it is not a predisposing factor for testicular malignancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning undescended testis, the following statements are true EXCEPT that it:
options: Is commoner on the right than on the left side.
Is bilateral in about 20% of cases.
Is rarely associated with inguinal hernia.
questions.explanation: Undescended testis is associated with a patent processus vaginalis (clinical inguinal hernia) in over 90% of cases, making the statement that it is 'rarely associated' false.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Empty scrotum may be due to:
questions.explanation: An empty scrotum can be caused by the absence of the testis (agenesis or vanishing testis from fetal torsion), failure to descend (arrested), or temporary retraction out of the scrotum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Indications of surgical correction of varicocele include the following except:
options: All cases should be treated surgically for fear of complications.
questions.explanation: Asymptomatic varicoceles without fertility issues do not require surgery. Treatment is reserved for cases with pain, infertility, or testicular atrophy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Inversion of testis may be:
questions.explanation: Inversion of the testis (abnormal lie) can be anterior (epididymis in front) or lateral, predisposing the testis to torsion.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common site of arrest of testis is:
questions.explanation: The inguinal canal is the most frequent site where testicular descent is arrested.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Radiosensitive testicular neoplasm is:
questions.explanation: Seminomas are highly radiosensitive tumors, whereas non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (like teratomas) are radioresistant and treated primarily with chemotherapy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding choriocarcinoma all are correct EXCEPT:
options: It is a subtype of teratoma.
questions.explanation: Choriocarcinoma is an aggressive tumor characterized by early hematogenous spread, most commonly to the lungs. Therefore, saying it 'rarely' gives lung metastasis is incorrect.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding incidence of testicular neoplasm:
options: Mostly occurs above 60 years of age.
questions.explanation: Approximately 95% of testicular tumors are malignant germ cell tumors. They typically affect young men (20-40 years), not the elderly.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding testicular tumors, the untrue is:
options: Seminomas and teratomas are more common thon non-germ cell tumors.
They have on increased incidence in undescended testis.
A-fetoprotein and B-HCG are tumor markers.
The treatment of choice is radical orchidectomy.
questions.explanation: While late-stage seminomas can spread to lungs, early hematogenous (pulmonary) spread is a hallmark of non-seminomatous tumors (like choriocarcinoma). Seminomas typically spread via lymphatics first.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Risk factors of testicular arrest include:
questions.explanation: Risk factors include family history, chromosomal abnormalities (like Down syndrome), maternal estrogen exposure, and conditions affecting placental function.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Size fluctuation is a character of:
questions.explanation: A congenital hydrocele communicates with the peritoneal cavity. Fluid drains back into the abdomen when recumbent (reducing size) and accumulates when upright (increasing size).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Testicular arrest is associated with urinary anomalies in:
questions.explanation: There is a significant association between undescended testes and upper urinary tract anomalies, occurring in approximately 10-20% of cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Testicular arrest is more:
questions.explanation: Undescended testis is more common on the right side because the right testis descends later than the left one.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Testis not found by laparoscopy may be due to:
questions.explanation: Non-visualization on laparoscopy may be due to testis agenesis, vanishing testis from vascular accident, or a hard-to-see location.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are complications of arrested testis:
questions.explanation: Undescended testes are at higher risk for torsion (due to developmental anomalies), trauma (compression against pubic bone), and malignancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about ectopic testis are true EXCEPT that it:
options: Is probably due to rupture of the scrotal tail of the gubernaculum.
May lie in the groin or pubic region.
Can be easily replaced in the scrotum.
questions.explanation: Unlike arrested (cryptorchid) testes which are often dysgenetic, ectopic testes usually develop normally and have a good prognosis if surgically relocated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The main disadvantage of paloma operation is:
questions.explanation: The Palomo operation (high retroperitoneal ligation) can have higher recurrence than microscopic subinguinal approaches due to missed collateral veins.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The management of testicular tumors includes the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Testicular biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of tumor spillage and lymphatic contamination of the scrotum. Diagnosis is based on tumor markers and imaging, followed by radical orchidectomy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most diagnostic investigation in arrested testis is:
questions.explanation: Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for locating non-palpable testes (intra-abdominal vs. absent).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The tunica vaginalis corresponds to:
questions.explanation: The tunica vaginalis is the serous covering of the testis derived from the peritoneum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is not true of interstitial cell tumors of testes:
options: Prepubertal tumors are from Sertoli cell.
Sertoli cell tumors are benign and orchidectomy is curative.
questions.explanation: Prepubertal stromal tumors are not exclusively Sertoli cell tumors; Leydig cell tumors also occur and cause precocious puberty. Thus, the statement implying exclusivity to Sertoli cells is false.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following has earlier pulmonary metastases:
questions.explanation: Choriocarcinoma has a very high propensity for rapid hematogenous spread, leading to early pulmonary metastases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most malignant testicular tumor is:
questions.explanation: Choriocarcinoma is considered the most malignant and aggressive histological type of testicular cancer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common presentation of testicular neoplasm is:
questions.explanation: The classic presentation is a painless, hard nodule or enlargement of the testis, often discovered accidentally by the patient.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In epididymo-orchitis, which of the following is false?
options: The causes are chlamydia and gonococci as sexually transmitted infections.
The initial symptoms are those of urinary tract infection (UTI).
In mumps 18 per cent of men may develop the condition.
It is a common postoperative complication after prostatectomy.
Treatment is doxycycline for chlamydia or a broad-spectrum antibiotic.
questions.explanation: Epididymo-orchitis is not a common complication of modern prostatectomy due to aseptic techniques and prophylactic antibiotics, unlike in the past.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The first LN station draining testis is:
questions.explanation: Lymphatic drainage follows the gonadal vessels to the para-aortic lymph nodes (level L1-L2), reflecting the embryological origin of the testis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The hazards of incomplete descent of testis include all the following EXCEPT:
options: Increased liability to malignant change in later life.
questions.explanation: Epididymo-orchitis is generally less common in undescended testes because the location protects them from retrograde spread of pathogens from the urethra.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true with regard to testicular torsion?
options: The typical symptom is sudden agonizing pain in the scrotum.
It is most common above 25 years of age.
Inversion of the testis and a transverse lie are not a cause.
Doppler ultrasound (US) scan should be done to confirm the diagnosis.
Emergency orchidopexy with non-absorbable sutures should be performed on both testes.
questions.explanation: The key point is that bilateral orchidopexy is mandatory to prevent recurrence and protect the contralateral testis; diagnosis is clinical to avoid delay.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false with regard to the management of testicular tumours?
options: Tumour markers are measured, and a chest X-ray carried out.
Initial surgical treatment is orchidectomy through the groin.
Staging is done by CT scan and MRI.
Secondaries from teratoma are always treated by surgery.
questions.explanation: Metastatic non-seminomatous germ cell tumors are mainly treated with chemotherapy; surgery is for residual masses. Saying “always surgery” is incorrect.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The 1st LN station draining testis is:
questions.explanation: Testicular lymphatics drain directly to the para-aortic lymph nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about spermatocele are correct except that it:
options: Is a retention cyst in the head of the epididymis
Occurs as a painless globular swelling fixed to the upper pole of the testis
questions.explanation: Spermatoceles are fluid-filled cysts (containing sperm) and are translucent (positive transillumination), not opaque.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Traction test is diagnostic of:
questions.explanation: The traction test (pulling the testis downwards causes the swelling to move downwards) is characteristic of an encysted hydrocele of the cord, as it is attached to the cord.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is confirmatory of encysted hydrocele of cord:
options: You can get above the swelling.
questions.explanation: A positive traction test confirms the attachment of the cystic swelling to the spermatic cord.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An adolescent male lifting a heavy weight develops sudden severe testicular, groin, and lower abdominal pain with vomiting, sweating, and collapse. Exam shows acutely tender, red, edematous inguinoscrotal swelling. He most likely has:
questions.explanation: Although the history of lifting might suggest hernia, the severity and autonomic symptoms (vomiting) strongly favor torsion.+ Sudden severe testicular pain and  acute scrotal signs.
questions.subject: General Surgery
